results.title: Art
results.brief_description: Presents a short and frantic history of painting and graphics, combined with Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony. Uses an animated still-picture technique, sometimes called “kinestasis”.

results.title: Arsenic and old lace
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Howard Lindsay, Russel Crouse and Frank Capra
results.brief_description: In this black comedy, Cary Grant plays Mortimer Brewster, a drama critic about to marry Elaine Page (Priscilla Lane) who discovers that insanity runs in his family. His maiden aunts poison lonely old men, and his uncle buries the victims in the cellar. Mortimer attempts to conceal these crimes as police search for the murderer. Grant donated his fee to war relief.

results.title: Arsenal
results.brief_description:
Revolution in the Ukraine in 1917-19, culminating in the suppression of the workers’ revolt in a munition factory at Kiev, is treated symbolically, employing the dynamics of montage in an epic celebration of victory in defeat. A blend of folklore, comedy, drama and caricature. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Director, Alexander Dovzhenko ; writers, Isaac Shpinel, Vladimir Muller ; photography, Daniel Demutski.
Cast: Semyon Svashenko, Mikola Nademsky, Ambrose Buchma, Pyotr Masokha.

results.title: Arrows against the wind
results.creator_credit: A Land Beyond Production, SBS-TV and Tracey Groome
results.brief_description: Describes the culture and traditional way of life of the indigenous peoples of West Papua (Irian Jaya), and the social, political and environmental upheaval they have endured since the beginning of Indonesian rule in 1963. Outlines their continuing struggle for social justice and self-determination.

results.title: Arrow up yours
results.creator_credit: Andrew Horne, Deborah Szapiro, Karl Kruszelnicki and Freerange Aninmation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Great moments in science: presented by Dr Karl Kruszelnicki”.
This entertaining animation presented by Karl Kruszelnicki explains the bow and arrow and its history and in so doing provides an explanation for the well known two finger salute. There is mention of the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, and how the well trained British used the Welsh long bow to attack the French. All this adds up to the reason behind the two finger salute.

results.title: Arrow to the sun
results.brief_description: A film which uses animation to tell the tale of the Acoma Pueblo Indians about a boy’s search for his father, entailing his voyage on an arrow to the Sun, trials he undergoes in the sky village until he is recognised by his father, the lord of the sun, and his return to earth to spread the sun’s warm delights. Based on the Caldecott Medal winning book by Gerald McDermott.

results.title: Arrivederci Roma
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Wright, Richard Zotorski, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Marinelli (Robert Forza) is a new immigrant to Australia who experiences difficulties when confronted with the harshness of the Anglo-saxon culture during a swimming lesson. With an inability to speak English, Marinelli is plunged into the deep end of the pool and cultural survival. Directed by Geoffrey Wright known mostly for ‘Romper Stomper’ and ‘Metal Skin’. Set in the City Baths, Melbourne.

results.title: Arrivederci Roma
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Richard Zatorski and Geoffrey Wright
results.brief_description: A new Australian comes to grips with his first physical education swimming lesson and makes some friends along the way to the deep end. Set in the City Baths, Melbourne. Stars Bill Banks, Rob Forza, Claudio Avilla and John White.

results.title: Arrival of sound
results.brief_description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. Actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the ‘Talkie Terror’, but when Don Juan and The Jazz Singer debuted, there was no turning back.

constellations_primary.name: Significant sounds
constellations_primary.description: The arrival of synchronised sound dramatically changed the movie business, allowing filmmakers to use sound in new and exciting ways which developed the use sound into own film language.

results.description: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. At first, actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the “Talkie Terror”. Though the first experiments began in the 1890s, it wasn’t until Don Juan in 1926 that a score and sound effects perfectly matched a movie, thanks to Warner Bros.’ Vitaphone system. The Jazz Singer (1927) went one step further, featuring not only synced music and sound effects but also the first recorded dialogue. Walt Disney was so impressed with the possibilities, he was inspired to create his own talking picture, Steamboat Willie (1928), which was not only one of the first cartoons with synchronised sound, it introduced the world to Mickey Mouse.
description_for_label: It was a huge shift for Hollywood when synchronised sound arrived in the late 1920s. At first, actors, studios and journalists resisted the new technology, and some even called it the “Talkie Terror”. Though the first experiments began in the 1890s, it wasn’t until Don Juan in 1926 that a score and sound effects perfectly matched a movie, thanks to Warner Bros.’ Vitaphone system. The Jazz Singer (1927) went one step further, featuring not only synced music and sound effects but also the first recorded dialogue. Walt Disney was so impressed with the possibilities, he was inspired to create his own talking picture, Steamboat Willie (1928), which was not only one of the first cartoons with synchronised sound, it introduced the world to Mickey Mouse.
